DataElement.preferredName: Leukemia French American British Morphology Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Alphanumeric code to represent the French American British (FAB) morphologic classification of leukemia.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Leukemia French American British Morphology Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to the grouping of hematologic malignancy (e.g., leukemia) based on criteria for morphologic and cytochemical appearance describe by the French-American-British international system._The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope._A classification system for acute myeloid leukemias, acute lymphoblastic leukemias, and myelodysplastic syndromes.  It is based on the morphologic and cytochemical evaluation of bone marrow and peripheral blood smears.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant (clonal) hematologic disorder, involving hematopoietic stem cells and characterized by the presence of primitive or atypical myeloid or lymphoid cells in the bone marrow and the blood.  Leukemias are classified as acute or chronic based on the degree of cellular differentiation and the predominant cell type present.  Leukemia is usually associated with anemia, fever, hemorrhagic episodes and splenomegaly.  Common leukemias include acute myeloid leukemia, chronic myelogenous leukemia, acute lymphoblastic or precursor lymphoblastic leukemia, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.  Treatment is vital to patient survival; untreated, the natural course of acute leukemias is normally measured in weeks or months, while that of chronic leukemias is more often measured in months or years. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A malignant (clonal) hematologic disorder, involving hematopoietic stem cells and characterized by the presence of primitive or atypical myeloid or lymphoid cells in the bone marrow and the blood. Leukemias are classified as acute or chronic based on the degree of cellular differentiation and the predominant cell type present. Leukemia is usually associated with anemia, fever, hemorrhagic episodes, and splenomegaly. Common leukemias include acute myeloid leukemia, chronic myelogenous leukemia, acute lymphoblastic or precursor lymphoblastic leukemia, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Treatment is vital to patient survival; untreated, the natural course of acute leukemias is normally measured in weeks or months, while that of chronic leukemias is more often measured in months or years.

Property.preferredDefinition: Morphology is the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.:A classification system for acute myeloid leukemias, acute lymphoblastic leukemias, and myelodysplastic syndromes. It is based on the morphologic and cytochemical evaluation of bone marrow and peripheral blood smears.:A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

Concepts.definition: The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.

A classification system for acute myeloid leukemias, acute lymphoblastic leukemias, and myelodysplastic syndromes.  It is based on the morphologic and cytochemical evaluation of bone marrow and peripheral blood smears.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text code terms to represent the marrow diagnostic category for a patient with acute leukemia._The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute biphenotypic leukaemia is a form of leukaemia where the lineage is of both lymphoid and myeloid origin; It is a subtype of

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute biphenotypic leukaemia is a form of leukaemia where the lineage is of both lymphoid and myeloid origin; It is a subtype of
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage characterized by blasts which coexpress myeloid and T or B lineage antigens or concurrent B and T lineage antigens.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage characterized by blasts which coexpress myeloid and T or B lineage antigens or concurrent B and T lineage antigens.  (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which the blasts do not show evidence of myeloid differentiation by morphology and conventional cytochemistry.  The myeloid origin of the blasts is demonstrated by immunohistochemistry and/or electron microscopic studies.  The patients present with anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.  The prognosis is usually poor.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Minimal Differentiation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which the blasts do not show evidence of myeloid differentiation by morphology and conventional cytochemistry. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute erythroid leukemias, including erythroleukemia (M6a) and very rare pure erythroid leukemia (M6b)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute erythroid leukemias, including erythroleukemia (M6a) and very rare pure erythroid leukemia (M6b)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by a predominant immature erythroid population.  There are two subtypes recognized: erythroleukemia and pure erythroid leukemia.  Severe anemia is a common symptom.  This leukemia usually follows an aggressive clinical course.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by a predominant immature erythroid population.  There are two subtypes recognized: erythroleukemia and pure erythroid leukemia. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute monoblastic leukemia (M5a) or acute monocytic leukemia (M5b)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute monoblastic leukemia (M5a) or acute monocytic leukemia (M5b)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemia in which 80% or more of the leukemic cells are of monocytic lineage, including monoblasts, promonocytes, and monocytes. Bleeding disorders are common presenting features. It usually follows an aggressive clinical course.

Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemia in which 80% or more of the leukemic cells are of monocytic lineage, including monoblasts, promonocytes, and monocytes. Bleeding disorders are common presenting features.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Myelomonocytic together with bone marrow eosinophilia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Myelomonocytic together with bone marrow eosinophilia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myelomonocytic leukemia characterized by the presence of abnormal bone marrow eosinophils. It is associated with inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22). It has a favorable prognosis.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia with Abnormal Eosinophils
Concepts.definition: Acute myelomonocytic leukemia characterized by the presence of abnormal bone marrow eosinophils. It is associated with inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22). It has a favorable prognosis.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute Promyelocytic leukemia characterized by the presence of hypergranular promyelocytes and characteristic cells that contain bundles of Auer rods.

Concepts.definition: Acute Promyelocytic leukemia characterized by the presence of hypergranular promyelocytes and characteristic cells that contain bundles of Auer rods.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute myeloblastic leukemia, with granulocytic maturation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute myeloblastic leukemia, with granulocytic maturation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts with evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. Patients often present with anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. AML with the t(8;21) is usually AML with maturation. This type of AML frequently responds to aggressive therapy. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts with evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils.  The patients present with anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.  This type of AML usually follows an aggressive clinical course.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not arranged or included in any specific grouping.

Concepts.definition: Not arranged or included in any specific grouping.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Not known or not well known

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Not known or not well known
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils.  The patients present with anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.  This type of AML usually follows an aggressive clinical course.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which at least 50% of the blasts are of megakaryocytic lineage.  The prognosis is usually poor.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which at least 50% of the blasts are of megakaryocytic lineage. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute promyelocytic leukemia in which the promyelocytes in the peripheral blood have paucity or absence of cytoplasmic granules and characteristic bilobed nuclei.

Concepts.definition: Acute promyelocytic leukemia in which the promyelocytes in the peripheral blood have paucity or absence of cytoplasmic granules and characteristic bilobed nuclei.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Morphology is the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
